newsitem.title: USA: Conn. appoints panel to run Hartford schools.
newsitem.headline: Conn. appoints panel to run Hartford schools.

text.p: The retired chief executive of distiller Heublein Inc will head up a state panel charged with turning around Hartford's troubled school system, Gov. John Rowland said Thursday.
Robert Furek, former president and chief executive of Heublein, will chair the seven-member board named by Rowland and legislative leaders.
Connecticut last month approved a dramatic state takeover of Hartford's crisis-torn school system, dissolving the Hartford Board of Education.
Other members of the new panel include a priest, a university administrator, a hospital official, a real estate businessman, a social services professional and a broadcast executive.
The appointees have agreed to serve as board members for three to five years.
The state-appointed trustees will try to rescue Hartford's $240 million school system plagued by chronic management problems and the lowest test scores in the state.
Dropout figures and teen pregnancy rates are also among Connecticut's worst.
Board chairman Furek led Heublein for 10 years and was known for boosting the company's profits during a time of declining alcohol consumption.
Hartford Mayor Mike Peters said on local radio that he was happy with the diverse composition of the panel.
"The people that they picked are very qualified," Peters said. "Now hopefully it will all come together in the next week or so."
Peters said he would press the trustees to put control of the schools back in the hands of principals and get rid of the top-heavy structure of administrators.
